extMath

Class ExtMath

  • java.lang.Object
    • extMath.ExtMath

  • public final class ExtMath
extends java.lang.Object
    This class serves as an extension of the Java Math library. While Math offers a lot of functions, it doesn't include some other helpful mathematical functions.
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Mattias De Charleroy

      Constructor and Description
      ExtMath()

    • Method Detail

      • gcd

        public static int gcd(int a,
      int b)
        This method returns the greatest common divisor of the a and b. This means that there is no larger integer which is divisible by a and b than the result of gcd(a,b).
        Parameters:
        a - The first argument whose gcd must be found with the second argument
        b - The second argument whose gcd must be found with the first argument
        Returns:
        Returns the greatest common divisor of the two arguments

      • gcd

        public static long gcd(long a,
       long b)
        This method returns the greatest common divisor of the a and b. This means that there is no larger long value which is divisible by a and b than the result of gcd(a,b).
        Parameters:
        a - The first argument whose gcd must be found with the second argument
        b - The second argument whose gcd must be found with the first argument
        Returns:
        Returns the greatest common divisor of the two arguments

      • lcm

        public static int lcm(int a,
      int b)
        This method returns the least common multiple of the a and b. This means that there is no smaller integer which is a multiple of a and b than the result of lcm(a,b).
        Parameters:
        a - The first argument whose lcm must be found with the second argument
        b - The second argument whose lcm must be found with the first argument
        Returns:
        Returns the least common multiple of the two arguments

      • lcm

        public static long lcm(long a,
       long b)
        This method returns the least common multiple of the a and b. This means that there is no smaller long which is a multiple of a and b than the result of lcm(a,b).
        Parameters:
        a - The first argument whose lcm must be found with the second argument
        b - The second argument whose lcm must be found with the first argument
        Returns:
        Returns the least common multiple of the two arguments

      • isPrime

        public static boolean isPrime(int number)
        This method determines if the given argument is prime or not in an efficient way.
        Parameters:
        number - The number to determine whether it is prime or not.
        Returns:
        Returns true if and only if the argument is prime.

      • isPrime

        public static boolean isPrime(long number)
        This method determines if the given argument is prime or not in an efficient way.
        Parameters:
        number - The number to determine whether it is prime or not.
        Returns:
        Returns true if and only if the argument is prime.

      • sieve

        public static boolean[] sieve(int n)
        This function creates and returns the sieve of Eratosthenes up to the given argument. More precisely if the number x is prime, sieve[x] == true, if x is not prime sieve[x] == false
        Parameters:
        n - The argument up to which number the sieve must be created
        Returns:
        Returns the sieve of Eratosthenes where sieve[x] is true if and only if x is prime

      • getPrimeFactors

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Long> getPrimeFactors(long number)
        This function returns all the prime factors and it's exponents of the given number
        Parameters:
        number - The argument of which the prime factorization must be found
        Returns:
        Returns a list of Longs where the ith place in the list represents the i/2 th smallest prime factor if i is even, if i is uneven it represents the exponent of the (i-1)/2 th prime factor. E.g. list.get(5) is the exponent belonging to the prime factor list.get(4) and this prime factor is the 4/2 = 2th smallest prime factor of the number

      • getDivisors

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Long> getDivisors(long number)
        This method returns all the divisors of the given number. The divisors are calculated using the prime factorization of the number
        Parameters:
        number - The number whose divisors are to be found
        Returns:
        Returns a list of all the divisors of the argument

      • getPrimeFactors

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> getPrimeFactors(int number)
        This function returns all the prime factors and it's exponents of the given number
        Parameters:
        number - The argument of which the prime factorization must be found
        Returns:
        Returns a list of Longs where the ith place in the list represents the i/2 th smallest prime factor if i is even, if i is uneven it represents the exponent of the (i-1)/2 th prime factor. E.g. list.get(5) is the exponent belonging to the prime factor list.get(4) and this prime factor is the 4/2 = 2th smallest prime factor of the number

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • solveSystem

        public static double[][] solveSystem(double[][] A,
                     double[][] b)
                              throws NoSingleSolutionException
        This function tries to solve a linear system of equations. This function solves the system of the form A*x = b if and only if there is only one single solution. It is possible to solve multiple systems at the same time with the same matrix A. E.g. |if you want to find A*x_1 = b A*x_2 = d A*x_3 = f You only need to give as parameter A and the matrix which contains each the vectors b,d,f. These vectors must be column vectors. The solution is given as column vectors. E.g. |if A = [1 0 and b = [1 3 | 0 1] 2 4] |then x = [1 3 | 2 4] Thus the solutions are for b_1 (1,2) are (1,2) and for b_2 (3,4) are (3,4).
        Parameters:
        A - The matrix which is a representation of the linear equations
        b - The argument where b = A*x
        Returns:
        Returns the solutions of the linear system for the given argument b. This two dimensional matrix will be a result in column vectors.
        Throws:
        NoSingleSolutionException - Thrown when the matrix A is singular, thus when the system as none, or an infinite amount of solutions.

      • solveSystem

        public static double[][] solveSystem(double[][] c)
                              throws NoSingleSolutionException
        This method is equivalent with solveSystem(A,b) where c = [A|b]. Thus c is the expanded matrix. See more info about this function at solveSystem(A,b)
        Throws:
        NoSingleSolutionException
